title: R41189
content: The President signed H.R. 1473 into law as P.L. 112-10 on April 15, 2011, representing the final appropriations act for FY2011. The law includes $41.6 billion in non-emergency discretionary spending for the Department of Homeland Security, with a 0.2% rescission for all departmental appropriations except for Coast Guard funding related to the global war on terrorism. P.L. 112-10 provides limited direction on how funds should be allocated, requiring the department to provide spending plans. Congress did not pass the 12 regular appropriations bills for FY2011 before the end of FY2010. Until P.L. 112-10 was signed into law on April 15, 2011, government funding levels for FY2011 were determined by a series of interim continuing resolutions, including P.L. 111-242, P.L. 111-290, P.L. 111-317, P.L. 111-322, P.L. 112-4, P.L. 112-6, and P.L. 112-8. These resolutions extended funding at FY2010 levels until the final appropriations act was passed. The second CR, P.L. 111-290, extended funding through December 18, 2010. The House passed the FY2011 full-year CR, H.R. 3082, on December 8, 2010. An interim CR, H.J.Res. 105, extended the expiration date to December 21, 2010. The Senate amended H.R. 3082 to extend funding at FY2010 levels, signed into law on December 22, 2010 as P.L. 111-322. Funding was further extended through March 4, 2011 with P.L. 111-322. The Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 was adopted on February 19, 2011. The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 (H.R. 1, 112th Congress) was passed on February 19, 2011. Further Continuing Appropriations Amendments, 2011 (H.J.Res. 44, 112th Congress) was introduced on February 28, 2011, to extend funding for two weeks. The legislation included reductions in funding for specific DHS accounts and programs. H.J.Res. 44 was passed by the House on March 1, 2011, by the Senate on March 2, 2011, and signed into law on March 3, 2011 (P.L. 112-4). It provided spending at FY2010 levels through March 18, 2011, with reductions in spending for DHS. The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 included reductions in funding for specific DHS accounts and programs, such as $1 million for logistics training, $43 million for facility construction projects, $20 million for cyber-security projects, and $103 million for university and emergency operations center grants. The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 included reductions in funding for specific DHS accounts and programs, such as logistics training, facility construction projects, cyber-security projects, and university and emergency operations center grants. P.L. 112-6 and P.L. 112-8 provided spending rates for all 12 regular bills through April 8, 2011, and April 15, 2011, respectively. The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 included reductions in funding for specific DHS accounts and programs. P.L. 112-8 provided a spending rate for all 12 regular bills through April 15, 2011, allowing time for the final year-long CR to be completed. The Senate Committee on Appropriations reported its version of the FY2010 DHS Appropriations bill on July 15, 2010, recommending a net appropriation of $45.2 billion for DHS for FY2011. The House Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security marked up its draft bill on June 24, 2010, but the bill was withdrawn before the full committee markup. The Administration requested a $45.0 billion budget for FY2011, a 2.4% increase from FY2010. Total budget authority for DHS in FY2011 was $52.6 billion. Net requested appropriations for major agencies within DHS were as follows: CBP $9,809 million, ICE $5,524 million, TSA $5,729 million, Coast Guard $9,867 million, Secret Service $1,570 million, National Protection & Programs Directorate $2,362 million. The Department of Homeland Security's budget for FY2011 included funding for various agencies such as Secret Service, National Protection & Programs Directorate, FEMA, Science and Technology, and the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office. Data sources for this report include the President's Budget Documents, Congressional Budget Justifications, and the Senate-reported version of S. 3607. The final direction given to DHS through P.L. 112-10 is outlined by title and component, detailing the President's FY2011 funding request for programs and activities. The report outlines President's FY2011 funding request for DHS programs and activities, comparing enacted FY2010 amounts to the FY2011 request. It tracks Senate recommendations and notes congressional issues related to discretionary funding amounts. No House recommendations are available for comparison. The report does not cover mandatory funding or legislation related to DHS programs. The Department of Homeland Security was created by an act that transferred functions, funding, and personnel from 22 agencies and offices. Appropriations for DHS are organized into five titles, covering management, security, preparedness, research, and general provisions. Title I includes funding for various offices within DHS, while Title II covers agencies like Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Transportation Security Administration, Coast Guard, and Secret Service. The U.S. Visitor and Immigrant Status Indicator Technology (US-VISIT) program was transferred to the National Protection & Programs Directorate (NPPD) in the FY2008 appropriation. This reorganization also included shifting programs and offices to eliminate the Preparedness Directorate and move some to FEMA, as proposed by the Administration and agreed upon by Congress. Title III in Division E of P.L. 110-161 reflects changes in appropriations for FEMA, USCIS, S&T, and FLETC. The congressional budget process determines the maximum budget authority for annual appropriations, with 302(a) allocations guiding discretionary totals for enactment in annual appropriations bills. The congressional budget process determines the maximum budget authority for annual appropriations through 302(a) allocations, which guide discretionary totals for enactment in annual appropriations bills. The appropriations committees allocate 302(b) discretionary funds among subcommittees, with these allocations forming the basis for enforcing budget discipline. Adjustments to 302(b) allocations may occur as appropriations bills progress towards final enactment. The annual concurrent resolution on the budget sets forth the congressional budget, with DHS's 302(b) allocations for FY2010 and the current appropriations cycle shown in Table 2. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation and determines the amounts available for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than enacted by Congress. Budget authority may be indefinite, available on a one-year, multi-year, or no-year basis. One-year budget authority is only available for obligation during a specific fiscal year. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. Obligations are incurred when agencies enter contracts, hire personnel, or receive services in a fiscal year. Outlays represent actual funds spent during the year, which may not always align with the budget authority enacted. Multi-year and no-year budget authority allow for obligations over multiple years, with some funds being spent in future fiscal years. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 defines discretionary appropriations as budget authority provided in annual appropriation acts and the outlays derived from that authority, but it excludes appropriations for entitlements. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, consists of budget authority and resulting outlays provided in laws other than appropriation acts and is typically not appropriated each year. Some mandatory entitlement programs must be appropriated each year and are included in the appropriations acts. Within DHS, the Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending. Offset funds collected by the federal government, either from government accounts or the public, are not counted as revenue but as negative outlays. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary spending. Some collections offset agency discretionary budget authority, while others offset mandatory spending for entitlement programs. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. Some entitlements are funded by permanent appropriations, while others are funded annually. The Secret Service retirement pay is a permanent appropriation, while the Coast Guard retirement pay is annually appropriated. Additionally, the DHS budget contains offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds, which are not appropriated by Congress but are included in the President's budget to calculate gross budget authority. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. Some entitlements are funded by permanent appropriations, while others are funded annually. The Secret Service retirement pay is a permanent appropriation, while the Coast Guard retirement pay is annually appropriated. Title I covers the general administrative expenses of DHS, including the Office of the Secretary and Executive Management (OSEM). The Office of the Secretary and 12 entities report directly to the Secretary, including the Under Secretary for Management and its components. New Title I accounts proposed for FY2011 were DHS Headquarters Consolidation and the National Special Security Event State and Local Reimbursement Fund. H.R. 1473 established funding levels for existing Title I accounts, with funding provided for OSEM, USM, CFO, and CIO compared to the President's request. The OIG would receive $114 million, plus $16 million from FEMA's disaster relief fund, as outlined in P.L. 111-83. $77 million for DHS Headquarters Consolidation is allocated for building projects. $53 million for the OCFO includes $4 million for financial systems consolidation efforts. Overall, funding levels reflect an $154 million, or 11.3% reduction from the Administration's request under Title I. The final legislation for FY2011 includes reductions in funding levels for Title I accounts, with an additional across-the-board rescission of budget authority. This results in a $452 million decrease from the President's request. Section 1656 of the legislation also rescinds $3 million in unobligated balances from Title I components, affecting OSEM and USM. The total FY2011 request for Title I accounts funded in FY2010 was $1,366 million, representing a 9.1% increase over the previous year. The FY2011 request for Title I accounts saw increases in funding for various components, with the largest increase in the OCIO account at 17.7%. The total FY2011 request for all Title I accounts was $1,749 million, representing a 39.7% increase over the FY2010 total. Additionally, two new accounts were introduced for FY2011, including the DHS Headquarters Consolidation request of $363 million and the National Special Security Event State and Local Reimbursement Fund request of $20 million. In FY2010, the largest increase in funding was requested for the OCIO, with $398 million and 309 FTEs, up from $338 million and 203 FTEs. The OCIO program increases include Information Technology Services ($56 million), Infrastructure and Security Activities ($186 million), and National Security Systems ($74 million). The next largest increase was in the OIG, with $130 million and 665 FTEs, up from $114 million and 632 FTEs. Within OIG, a $4 million increase was requested for Audit, Inspections, and Investigations for various TSA initiatives. The FY2011 funding request for the OFCGCR was not requested as the office closed in March 2010. The new DHS Headquarters Consolidation account aims to provide improved visibility and management of DHS facilities. $363 million was requested to support the consolidation of mission support elements and headquarters to the St. Elizabeths Campus. The NSSE State and Local Reimbursement Fund will be administered by the Office of Operations Coordination and Planning. The Office of Operations Coordination and Planning manages National Special Security Events (NSSEs) such as presidential inaugurations and major international meetings. A $20 million appropriation is requested to reimburse state and local governments for security costs. Specific provisions included funding for the development of the DHS Consolidated Headquarters and lease consolidation in the National Capital Region. The Chief Administrative Officer is directed to provide regular briefings on the consolidation plan. $50 million for the OSEM appropriation is contingent on the Secretary submitting a comprehensive risk assessment and national security strategy for the railroad sector. The Senate committee recommended funding reductions for different departments compared to the President's request, including $50 million for the OSEM appropriation contingent on a comprehensive risk assessment and national security strategy for the railroad sector. Additionally, $25 million would be withheld until a plan for a biometric air exit capability is submitted, and $20 million would be allocated for Visa Waiver Program negotiations. $5 million from the USM appropriation would fund facility alterations for consolidating DHS headquarters operations. The plan should focus on areas where DHS can provide unique expertise and serve intelligence customers not supported by other intelligence community components. The CFO is required to submit monthly budget and staffing reports. The OCHCO manages human resources at DHS and provides oversight and guidance. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 established the Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection Directorate within DHS to identify and assess terrorist threats. The Office of Information Analysis was renamed the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, with the Assistant Secretary for Intelligence Analysis designated as the Chief Intelligence Officer. Funding for CBP was provided as follows compared to the President's request: Salaries and Expenses, $8,213 million ($5 million, or 0.1% above); Automation Modernization, $337 million ($11 million, or 3.2% below); Border Security Fencing, Infrastructure and Technology, $574 million (even); Air and Marine Interdiction, $516 million ($13 million, or 2.6% above); and Construction and Facilities Management, $260 million ($20 million, or 7% below). In FY2010, ICS was operational in six ports and scanning 100% of containers at select locations. The President's FY2011 budget proposed a reduction in funding for ICS by nearly $17 million. The proposed $58 million reduction in CSI funding will shift operations to the National Targeting Center-Cargo (NTC-C) for targeting high-risk containers. The Senate-reported budget provided more funding than the Administration requested, reflecting the diverse activities ICE undertakes to enforce civil and criminal laws. ICE's resource allocation for its mission is a contentious issue, especially regarding the detention and removal of aliens. There is debate on the prioritization of criminal aliens for deportation and the balance with other responsibilities like terrorist travel and worksite enforcement. Less than one-third of those deported by ICE in FY2008 and FY2009 were convicted of a criminal offense. ICE's Detention and Removal Operations (DRO) manages custody of aliens in removal proceedings or ordered removed from the US. Concerns exist about insufficient detention space leading to decisions on release based on space availability rather than individual cases. The debate over the role of state and local law enforcement in enforcing federal immigration laws has raised concerns about training, resources, civil rights violations, and community impact. While some argue that federal resources are limited and state and local entities should assist, others question the implications of such partnerships. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is responsible for protecting air, land, and rail transportation systems in the United States against terrorist threats. It was created by the Aviation and Transportation Security Act and transferred to the Department of Homeland Security in 2002. The TSA deploys passenger and baggage screeners, detection systems, and other security technologies to ensure the safety of transportation systems. State and local entities can apply for additional funding through appropriations to the Office of State and Local Government Coordination in FEMA. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is responsible for protecting air, land, and rail transportation systems in the United States against terrorist threats. TSA assesses the risk of terrorist attacks to non-aviation transportation assets, issues regulations, and enforces them to improve security. The President's request for TSA budget in FY2011 was $8,165 million, with a 7% increase over FY2010 enacted levels.
